newsitem.title: UK: Options-Coffee volatility mixed, cocoa still quiet.
newsitem.headline: Options-Coffee volatility mixed, cocoa still quiet.

text.p: Coffee options volatilities were mixed this week as investors tried to figure out which direction coffee would take next.
Meanwhile, cocoa options remained fairly inactive despite a steep rise amid active futures trading that pushed July and September to fresh contract highs.
In coffee, traders said July volatilities rose to 100 percent or more across the board with only six days left to trade.
But September volatilities slid about 10 percent this week. Traders pegged implied at-the-money September volatility near 64 percent, down from the mid- to high-70s a week ago.
November volatility was seen about flat, between 58 and 59 percent.
Traders attributed the drop in September to forecasts of warm weather moving into Brazil as well as a calmer, more rangebound market in the past couple of days.
"They are probably discounting a frost," a trader said.
Coffee options activity was also mixed, with skew favouring neither puts nor calls. Most trading was also done earlier in the week, traders said.

They said options have quieted as investors digest coffee's violent gyrations in the past few weeks. New York arabica futures hit 20-year highs last month but quickly fell back to six-week lows on Wednesday.
Traders said activity in London's July coffee options continued to centre around out-of-the-money calls between about $1,900 and $2,800.
In September, traders saw mostly local interest in September $1,700 calls and puts.
In cocoa, options remained quiet with only about 75 contracts changing hands on Thursday despite a futures buying frenzy.
By midday, 25 September 1,000 puts and 50 September 1,025 puts changed hands. Traders said locals were the main buyers of the 1,025-stg puts at 24.5 percent voaltility.

July and September cocoa futures scored new contract highs on worries that the developing El Nino weather pattern would cause drought in many cocoa-producing regions, including Southeast Asia and the Ivory Coast.
Talk that Ivory Coast settings for the new crop also buoyed prices, traders said.
Funds joined the buying spree after July and September drove through triple resistances to break out of a flag formation on the charts, traders said.
But options activity has remained subdued as underlying futures prices moved swiftly. Traders speculated that once cocoa futures settle down, options might pick up.

Implied at-the-money cocoa options volatilities were slightly up for the week as of Wednesday's close but slightly lower from Tuesday due to the lack of interest. At-the-money implied July volatility was about 22.5 percent, down from 27 percent earlier in the week, traders said.
September was seen between 22.5 and 23.5 percent and December near 24.5 percent.
--Medora Lee, London newsroom +44 171 542 8072
